head.ce:title: Study of the impact of the MAIA care management system on the readmission to hospital of patients aged 75 and over
head.ce:alt-title: #$#Eacute;tude de l#$#rsquo;impact d#$#rsquo;une prise en charge MAIA sur la r#$#eacute;hospitalisation des patients #$#acirc;g#$#eacute;s de 75#$#nbsp;ans et plus

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: P#$#ocirc;le sant#$#eacute; publique et performance, Centre Hospitalier de Troyes, France
Comit#$#eacute; universitaire de ressources pour la recherche en sant#$#eacute; (CUR2S), Universit#$#eacute; de Reims Champagne Ardennes, France
P#$#ocirc;le Sant#$#eacute; Autonomie, CHU de Reims, France
P#$#ocirc;le hospitalo-universitaire de g#$#eacute;rontologie clinique, CHU de Nantes, France

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Discharge from hospital is a key moment in the care of patients over 75 years of age. The organisation of the transition from hospital to home through home help and care management networks can be effective. Our aim was to evaluate the impact of a case management approach on the rate of rehospitalisation at 30 days.
Retrospective multicentre cohort study carried out on patients monitored by the Aube MAIA between 2018 and 2020.

The risk of readmission to hospital was significantly lower at 30 days among MAIA patients (1.6% vs. 19.5%; P#$#lt;0.0001), as well as at 90 days (4.8 % vs. 35.8 %; P#$#lt;0.0001). In contrast, the length of stays was longer in this group (20.9 vs. 11 days; P=0.005) and the patients consulted the emergency department more often (40.8% vs. 17.1%; P#$#lt;0.0001). Conclusions could not be drawn on mortality and falls.
A positive impact of the Aube MAIA scheme on early and later readmission to hospital was shown.

La sortie d#$#rsquo;hospitalisation est un moment cl#$#eacute; dans la prise en charge du patient #$#acirc;g#$#eacute; de plus de 75#$#nbsp;ans. L#$#rsquo;organisation de la transition h#$#ocirc;pital-domicile par des r#$#eacute;seaux d#$#rsquo;aides au domicile et de #$#laquo;#$#nbsp;care management#$#nbsp;#$#raquo; peut #$#ecirc;tre efficace. L#$#rsquo;hypoth#$#egrave;se est que ce dispositif permet une r#$#eacute;duction des taux d#$#rsquo;hospitalisation #$#agrave; 30#$#nbsp;jours.
#$#Eacute;tude r#$#eacute;trospective de type cohorte multicentrique r#$#eacute;alis#$#eacute;e sur les patients suivis par la MAIA de l#$#rsquo;Aube entre 2018#$#nbsp;et 2020.

Le risque de r#$#eacute;hospitalisation #$#eacute;tait significativement plus faible #$#agrave; 30#$#nbsp;jours parmi les patients MAIA (1,6#$#nbsp;#$#nbsp;% vs 19,5#$#nbsp;%#$#nbsp;; p #$#lt;#$#nbsp;0,0001), ainsi qu#$#rsquo;#$#agrave; 90#$#nbsp;jours (4,8#$#nbsp;% vs 35,8#$#nbsp;%#$#nbsp;; p #$#lt;#$#nbsp;0,0001). En revanche, les dur#$#eacute;es de s#$#eacute;jour #$#eacute;taient plus longues dans ce groupe (20,9#$#nbsp;vs 11#$#nbsp;jours#$#nbsp;; p =#$#nbsp;0,005) et les patients consultaient plus souvent aux urgences (40,8#$#nbsp;% vs 17,1#$#nbsp;%#$#nbsp;; p #$#lt;#$#nbsp;0,0001). Nous n#$#rsquo;avons pas pu conclure sur la mortalit#$#eacute; et les chutes.
Un impact positif du dispositif MAIA de l#$#rsquo;Aube sur la r#$#eacute;hospitalisation pr#$#eacute;coce et tardive a #$#eacute;t#$#eacute; montr#$#eacute;.

ce:section.ce:para: The world#$#apos;s population is ageing, with the number of older people increasing most markedly in industrialised countries [1]. France is no exception, and the number of people over 75 years old has almost doubled in the past 30 years, reaching six million and representing 10% of the French population in 2019 [2].

According to INSEE, Champagne-Ardenne has been ageing more than the rest of metropolitan France since 2007 [3], with the projection that a quarter of its population will be aged 65 or over by 2027 and growing strongly from 2021. At the same time, almost 40% of the over 75s live alone [4].

Over the course of a year, one-third of patients aged 75 or over will be hospitalised at least once and one-sixth at least twice. The average cost of hospital stays for these patients is #$#z.euro;6,000 per person per year [5] and this varies according to the frailty of the patient [6]. In this context, discharge from hospital is key to preventing and supporting future hospital admissions for people over 75 years of age.

The rate of early, unscheduled rehospitalisation within 30 days of discharge varies between 14 and 20% in this age group, depending on the study [7-10]. A quarter of these readmissions to hospital could be avoidable [11]. Some of these readmissions reflect acute pathologies, whether infectious and/or with cardiac or pulmonary involvement. Other episodes of rehospitalisation are linked to the patient#$#apos;s frailty, with a strong impact of functional disorders, in addition to socio-economic determinants such as financial instability. Ultimately, these factors are associated with a risk of rehospitalisation [12,#$#nbsp;13], which is associated with a risk of death [14].

To reduce the risk of rehospitalisation, in 2013, the French Haute Autorit#$#eacute; de Sant#$#eacute; (HAS) proposed that the transition between hospital and home should be better organised [15], starting with an assessment of frailty during the hospital stay, followed by better communication between the community medical team and the hospital, and finally the continuation at home of the treatment initiated in the hospital. Various home help networks for the elderly and/or frail exist, but these services are often uncoordinated, and the patient#$#apos;s GP is only involved in half of the cases [16,#$#nbsp;17]. However, these approaches have shown some effectiveness [18,#$#nbsp;19].

International experiments such as the Accountable Care Organizations (ACO) have shown the benefits of better coordination, particularly with regard to readmission to hospital at an early stage and up to one year later [20,#$#nbsp;21]. Benefits in terms of healthcare expenditure (acute hospitalisations, supplementary examinations, rehabilitation and emergency department use) [22,#$#nbsp;23] have also been demonstrated. Thus, transposing the French care management system could improve the quality of care, in particular by reducing rehospitalisation rates at 30 days [24].

The #$#ldquo;Parcours Sant#$#eacute; des A#$#icirc;n#$#eacute;s#$#rdquo; (PAERPA) experiments set up in 2014 aimed to improve the care and quality of life of people aged 75 or over by improving local coordination between different healthcare professionals. In particular, they studied rates of readmission to hospital at 30 days, unscheduled hospitalisations, length of stay and emergency department visits. The results differed across the regions and there was no impact on the national level on the reduction of hospitalisations [25,#$#nbsp;26].

The M#$#eacute;thode d#$#rsquo;Action pour l#$#rsquo;Int#$#eacute;gration des Services d#$#rsquo;Aide et de Soins dans le Champ de l#$#rsquo;Autonomie (MAIA) is a #$#ldquo;care management#$#rdquo; system aimed at people over 60 who are losing their independence and who may have Alzheimer#$#apos;s disease or a related condition. It aims to improve coordination between care providers, simplify care pathways, avoid breaks in continuity of care, and make it easier for people to stay at home. The effectiveness of this approach has never been evaluated on various outcomes, including the patient#$#apos;s readmission to hospital at 30 days. The main hypothesis is that this approach leads to a reduction in the rate of early hospitalisation, i.e. within 30 days. In this context, the main objective of our study is to study the impact of the MAIA system in the Aube region on the time to readmission to hospital of patients aged 75 and over.

This was a multicentre, retrospective, observational cohort study aimed at describing the pathways taken by patients integrated into the MAIA system after hospitalisation in two hospitals (the Centre Hospitalier de Troyes [CHT], and the Groupement Hospitalier Aube-Marne [GHAM]), who were considered to be #$#ldquo;at-risk patients#$#rdquo; and a control group of #$#ldquo;not at-risk patients#$#rdquo;, hospitalised during the same period.

The case population consisted of patients admitted to the Aube MAIA between January 2018 and October 2020 after a hospital stay. The group of #$#ldquo;control patients#$#rdquo; was drawn at random with a 1:1 ratio without replacement from the hospital databases and individually matched on age, sex, Charlson score, year of entry with a tolerance of five years maximum difference and, if possible, within the same period within the year of entry. Inclusion criteria were that patients were hospitalised during the study period, were over 75 years of age and did not object to the re-use of their data.

The primary endpoint of this study was the occurrence of readmission to hospital within 30 days of discharge. Our secondary endpoints were rehospitalisation within 90 days, length of hospital stay, number of emergency department visits and occurrence of death during the follow-up period. The data were collected by consulting medical reports in the computerised patient file of the hospitals considered.

The variables studied included the patient#$#apos;s date of birth, gender, date of entry and exit from the MAIA, date of death, and the facility responsible (R#$#eacute;seau G#$#eacute;rontologie et M#$#eacute;moire de l#$#rsquo;Aube [R#$#eacute;G#$#eacute;MA], or the Aube departmental council). The R#$#eacute;G#$#eacute;MA scheme applied to patients in urban areas and that of the departmental council to areas outside urban areas. During hospitalisation, the mode of entry, and the dates of entry and discharge were recorded to calculate the length of stay and the time to readmission to hospital. The hospital stays of interest for our study were the last stay before admission to the MAIA scheme, whether scheduled or unscheduled, and the first unscheduled stay after admission to the scheme. Other subsequent unscheduled hospitalisations during the MAIA follow-up period were also counted. The total number of emergency visits during the follow-up period was recorded.

Variables concerning lifestyle and socio-economic context were also recorded: marital status (married, widowed or single), presence or otherwise of close family, home care worker, independence (independent patient, partial independence or dependent), confinement to bed, nutritional status (BMI), cognitive status (presence of described cognitive disorder and MMSE); the number of drug treatments, possible alcohol or tobacco intoxication, falls at home, and Charlson score were collected.

The primary endpoint was the occurrence of readmission to hospital within 30 days. This rate was estimated using the calculation tool produced by the Agence Technique de l#$#rsquo;Information Hospitali#$#egrave;re (ATIH).

The quantitative variables were described as mean with standard deviation in the case of a normal distribution, otherwise the median and interquartile range were presented. Categorical variables were presented by numbers and percentages. The normality of the variables was assessed graphically and by the Shapiro-Wilk test.

Comparisons between the two groups were made using pairwise stratified logistic regression. Variables associated with the group of at-risk patients (P#$#lt;0.10) were included in a top-down logistic regression model, using a value of P#$#gt;0.10 as an acceptability threshold. The variables that were retained in this selection model were then used as an adjustment factor in the primary and secondary criterion analysis.
Cumulative incidence curves were constructed using the Kaplan-Meier method and compared using the log-rank test.

The risk of readmission to hospital at 30 and 90 days, as well as the risk of death, were compared between the two groups using a pairwise stratified Cox model adjusted for the selected parameters. The proportional hazard hypothesis was tested using Schoenfeld residuals. The length of hospital stay and the risk of falling were compared using a pair-matched stratified logistic regression model.
Statistical tests were performed, with a bilateral #$#alpha;-level of 0.05 considered as significant. Data were analysed using SAS#$#reg; version 9.4 software (SAS Institute#$#reg;, Cary, NC).

An agreement was signed between R#$#eacute;G#$#eacute;MA, the Aube departmental council and the promoter of the study for the use of the data of the patients included in the system. In accordance with current legislation, the requirement for written informed consent or advice from an ethics committee was not necessary, as the study was strictly observational, and all data were anonymised [27]. As the CHT complied with the MR004 commitment, a no-objection search was carried out and the study was registered in the directory of studies under the reference methodology.

A total of 386 patients entered the MAIA system. Sixty-eight patients were under 75 years of age and were not included. Four patients could not be matched. Ultimately, 314 MAIA patients could be analysed, of which 158 were followed by R#$#eacute;G#$#eacute;MA (corresponding to the #$#ldquo;urban MAIA#$#rdquo; subgroup) and 156 were followed by the departmental council (corresponding to the #$#ldquo;non-urban MAIA#$#rdquo; subgroup). Three hundred and fourteen non-MAIA patients were matched for analysis. This is summarised below in figure 1.
The characteristics are presented in table 1, with three subgroups: non-MAIA, Urban MAIA and Non-urban MAIA.

In 92.4% of cases, patients were matched for the same quarter of the year, i.e., for 290 out of 314 non-MAIA patients. The average age was 85 years (#$#plusmn; 5 years) for MAIA patients and 84 years (#$#plusmn; 6 years) for non-MAIA patients. MAIA patients were more likely to live alone (34.2% and 27.6% vs. 23.3%; P#$#lt;0.0001) and were more independent than non-MAIA patients (62.8% and 63.3% vs. 58.6%; P#$#lt;0.0001). They also had more cognitive problems than the other group (44.9% and 39.1%) vs. 24.5%; P#$#lt;0.0001). The BMI of urban MAIA and non-urban MAIA patients was lower than that of non-MAIA patients (24.2 and 25.9 vs. 27.1; P=0.0007). They also had fewer treatments (7 and 6 vs. 9; P#$#lt;0.0001). Finally, the presence of a home care worker was twice as high among non-MAIA patients (22.6% vs. 10.8% and 9%; P#$#lt;0.0001).

Of the MAIA patients, 223 (71.01%) had already been hospitalised before entering the scheme. One hundred and sixty-six (52.9%) had a second hospital stay and 64 (20.4%) had a third hospital stay. These results are presented in table 2. In subgroup analyses, urban patients were hospitalised more frequently than non-urban patients. For all groups, the first-stay hospitalisations were unscheduled in 77.6% of cases. Subsequent stays were admissions via the emergency department in the majority of cases.

Also in table 2, the percentage of outpatient emergency department visits was 40.8% for MAIA patients compared to 17.1% for non-MAIA patients (P#$#lt;0.0001). Non-urban patients consulted the least (64.1%) vs. 54.4%; P#$#lt;0.0001) (figure 2).

Thirty days after discharge, 60 patients were readmitted to hospital. These results are presented in table 3. The risk was significantly lower among MAIA patients (1.6% vs. 19.5%; P#$#lt;0.0001 table 3, figure 3A). After adjusting for the presence of a home care worker and cognitive impairment, the association remained significant (HR=0.19; 95% CI 0.070.49; P=0.0001). At 90 days, the same results were observed (35.8% vs. 4.8%; P#$#lt;0.0001) and after adjustment, the association remained significant (HR=0.21; 95% CI 0.12#$#ndash;0.38; P#$#lt;0.0001) (table 3 and figure 3B).

At 90 days, there were moderately more hospitalisations in the non-urban MAIA patients (5.8% vs. 3.9%). Hospitalisations at 30 and 90 days after entering the MAIA system concerned 9.5% and 19.7% of patients; these elements are presented in the supplement to table 1. During the 12 months following discharge from the first hospital stay, 56% of MAIA patients were not readmitted to hospital, 27.7% were readmitted once, 7.3% were readmitted twice and, finally, 3.8% were readmitted to hospital three times (figure 4). For non-MAIA patients, the results were 43.9%, 8.0%, 23.9% and 24.2%, respectively. The average number of hospital stays over the 12 months was 0.6 for MAIA patients and 1.3 for non-MAIA patients (P#$#lt;0.0001).

The average length of stay for the rehospitalisation was longer for MAIA patients than for non-MAIA patients at 20.9 days (#$#plusmn; 28.1) vs. 11 days (#$#plusmn; 11.8) (P=0.005). In contrast, no significant difference was observed for the third hospital stay (table 3). The length of the stays of non-urban MAIA patients were longer, at 23.9 days (#$#plusmn; 29) and 25.3 days (#$#plusmn; 30.9), respectively (P#$#lt;0.0001).

Finally, MAIA patients had a higher risk of falling (OR, 2.65; 95% CI, 1.81#$#ndash;3.86; P#$#lt;0.0001). This association no longer persists after adjusting for the presence of a home care worker and/or cognitive impairment. (P=0.08), except in the urban MAIA subgroup (OR, 2.62; 95% CI 1.54#$#ndash;4.46; P=0.0004).

Of the 314 MAIA patients, one patient died within three months of discharge, compared to 57 deaths among non-MAIA patients. A description of all MAIA post-inclusion deaths is presented in the supplement to table 2 and shows the time period in years after the hospital stay or entry to the MAIA.

Our results show the beneficial effects of MAIA care for people aged 75 or more with regards to readmission to hospital at 30 days and one year. These results suggest the effectiveness of this care management scheme on the rate of rehospitalisation after inclusion in the scheme.

In patients aged 75 years and over, the 30-day rehospitalisation rate has been quantified in the literature as 14#$#ndash;20% [7-10] and this is seen as relevant in the follow-up of the population [8]. The 90-day rehospitalisation rate is a marker that also reflects the transition from hospital to home and takes into account outpatient care [15]. The rates are in the range of 31#$#ndash;34% in studies [10,#$#nbsp;28]. In our control group, rates were consistent with these at 19.5% and 35.8%, respectively. In our study, the MAIA group had re-hospitalisation rates of 1.6%at 30 days and 4.8% at 90 days. In the literature, the reduction in the rehospitalisation rate has been achieved by educating patients#$#rsquo; families and friends, informing caregivers at discharge, and coordinating care and early visits [29,#$#nbsp;30]. However, these studies show highly variable reduction rates and rarely exceed a 25% reduction in rehospitalisation [31].

Our study also shows beneficial effects over 12 months with half as many hospital admissions for the MAIA group. In the literature, the improvement in rehospitalisation rates at this time is 13% [21]. Our results again show much lower rates of readmission to hospital in the long term than in the literature.

While our results show lower rates of rehospitalisation, the lengths of the stays were longer and emergency visits were more frequent. According to the literature, the length of stay is between eight and nine days, which corresponds to our control group [32-35]. It is a marker in relation to functional decline, the shorter the stay, the more beneficial it is for the elderly patient, particularly in terms of mortality [33,#$#nbsp;36]. Longer hospital stays in patients with dementia have been described [37]. This is explained by a more severe pathology or decompensation and more frequent infectious pathologies [38]. It can be added that MAIA patients are more likely to live alone at home with fewer domestic carers and this has an impact on the length of their stay in hospital, particularly for women [39]. Moreover, in the non-MAIA group, 7.3% of the patients lived in a care facility for dependent elderly people (Ehpad), thus making early discharge easier in this group.

Sixty-eight per cent of people over 75 years of age visited an emergency department within a year [40]. In addition, emergency departments are experiencing an increase in geriatric consultations, and such visits can be deleterious. Our study found higher rates of emergency room visits in the MAIA group (40.8% vs. 17.1%). However, there is evidence of the effects of care management schemes on emergency admission rates within three months [41]. Another study showed no difference in the use of emergency care upon entry into a care management schemes [42]. Our population was more prone to using emergency care services, which is probably specific to the characteristics of these patients and to the local healthcare available, particularly outpatient care.

Mortality in elderly patients is six times higher within three months of discharge from hospital [7]. In the SAFES cohort, mortality occurred within a median of 215 days, 34.1% of patients died at one year, 44% at two years and 49.7% at three years [14]. The same study described early readmission to hospital as a risk factor for death. Patients who do not return to hospital very often, such as those in the MAIA group, may then have a lower risk of death, although the low number of deaths does not allow the results to be interpreted.

With regard to falls, these may be associated with the frailty of the older person [43]. Half of the MAIA patients were known to have fallen. These results are in line with the literature on the increase in falls in patients with dementia [44]. As our study was retrospective, it did not show a reduction in falls and conclusions cannot be drawn as to whether this scheme reduces the risk of falling.

Our population differed from the control group, and this constitutes a bias, mainly related to cognitive impairment in MAIA patients. This was to be expected, as historically this approach was created to support patients with cognitive disorders.

Secondly, home care workers, twice as numerous in the MAIA group and prescribed for #$#ldquo;monitoring drug intake#$#rdquo; in almost two-thirds of these patients, seem to be linked to the number of treatments, which are less prescribed here. Indeed, we know that cognitive disorders can lead to a higher risk of iatrogenic disorders [45,#$#nbsp;46] and be a factor in hospitalisation [47]. This seems to reflect another benefit of the MAIA system in terms of preventing iatrogeny, and partially explains the reduction in rehospitalisation.

The patients in the MAIA group were more independent and more often lived alone, especially in the non-urban MAIA group. This isolation is known to increase co-morbidities as well as mortality and emergency room visits [48]. It is also related to a longer length of stay in hospital [49]. This last point is observed in the non-urban MAIA sub-group, unlike the number of emergency room visits, which can be explained by the geographical isolation of these patients far from healthcare centres.

Finally, a selection bias can be described, as the MAIA follows patients at home and therefore excludes patients living in institutions who are described as more fragile [50]. Living in an institution is also a feature of the non-MAIA group.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Strengths and limitations of the study
ce:section.ce:para: The strength of our study is that it evaluates the effectiveness of a care management system over several years in several hospitals, thus reducing the risk of significant seasonality when evaluating rehospitalisation and hospitalisation rates. In addition, the control group was consistent with the literature on the subject. However, our study has real limitations.

Firstly, regarding the low figures on readmission to hospital. We can assume that these figures are underestimated. This could be due to the time period between discharge from hospital and entry into the MAIA scheme being too long. Indeed, arrangements for entry into the MAIA scheme is not systematically carried out immediately after discharge from hospital, thus inducing a bias in the study of early rehospitalisation. This variable inclusion time cannot be controlled with our study design. It is also possible that there is a selection bias when patients enter the MAIA scheme. Indeed, these patients are more independent and have better potential to remain at home, suggesting they are less frail. Finally, it may be a lack of events in our sample or a lack of availability of beds in the department.

Secondly, the chosen design of the study does not fully control for indication bias. Indeed, since the patients referred to the system are more prone to cognitive disorders, this limits the comparability of the groups despite our matching on age, sex, inclusion period and Charlson score. Secondly, the retrospective nature of the study leads to a lack of control of certain variables, which are sometimes missing and/or subjective in the medical records. This was the case for the #$#ldquo;cognitive impairment#$#rdquo; and #$#ldquo;independence#$#rdquo; variables. Indeed, cognitive disorders were described as present or absent, but objective criteria of dementia, such as the MMSE, were poorly documented in both groups, at 16.5% in the non-MAIA group and 27.7% in the MAIA group. This was also the case for the description of independence, where there was little mention of ADL/IADL.

Thirdly, the population described remains that of the Aube department. Even if an adjustment was made for the inclusion period, it cannot fully take into account a centre effect and a centre saturation effect, depending on the period. This could potentially reduce the quality of care and increase the risk of rehospitalisation. While the matching partially controls for this bias, there may still be a residual effect that cannot be estimated in our models. There is therefore another bias related to the regional nature of the evaluation.

Our study, therefore, made it possible to evaluate the impact of the MAIA system, in the context of the care of people over 75 years of age, on readmission to hospital within a French department. It has shown encouraging benefits in terms of early and later readmission to hospital. However, we note increased lengths of stay and emergency visits, which may be linked to the specific characteristics of these patients. These differences seem to be related to cognitive disorders, which are more frequent in the MAIA group. However, we were unable to draw conclusions on the reduction of mortality and the occurrence of falls.

Such improvements in rehospitalisation rates would need to be evaluated on a national scale to confirm the results of our study. In order to better evaluate a care management system, a prospective patient follow-up study should be established to study the occurrence of events: time, number and duration of unscheduled hospital readmissions within 30 days, three months and one year; time and number of emergency visits, deaths and even falls within three months.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The authors would like to thank R#$#eacute;G#$#eacute;MA (Armelle Pi#$#eacute;ton and Fabienne Bon) and the Conseil D#$#eacute;partemental (Victor Langlet, Dr. Sylvie Plique, Dr Elodie R#$#eacute;gnier) for their help and participation in this evaluation project.

ce:section.ce:para: None of the authors have any conflicts of interests to disclose.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Global aging: the challenge of success
